narratives.name: Manufacturing Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-9 DEEP DIVE (first ever): 12.87M workers, 392K establishments, $82,575 avg pay, $1.06T total wages. Baumol 1.14x (moderate — transformation is ADDITIVE not substitutional). 6 sub-sectors analyzed: Food (311: 1.73M emp, Baumol 0.82, robot orders +85.6%), Fabricated Metal (332: 1.44M emp, most fragmented at 60.7K establishments), Machinery (333: 1.18M emp, CNC/digital twin frontier), Computer/Electronic (334: 1.06M emp, CHIPS Act driven), Transportation Equipment (336: 1.88M emp, EV transition + reshoring), Plastics (326: 600K emp, classic Baumol release -2.1% emp/+4.1% wages). P-041 candidate: Manufacturing Modernization Bimodality (top 1% AI-sophisticated, bottom 72% on spreadsheets). Manufacturing is MOST ACTIONABLE sector: extreme fragmentation + demographic pressure + proven cobot tech + reshoring tailwind + low fear friction + ADDITIVE transformation. 12 new model cards, 3 WIDE_OPEN, 9 ACCESSIBLE. Avg Transformation 77.8, avg Opportunity 69.4.

2026.description: Disruption underway in Manufacturing. First entrants proving viability. Incumbents beginning to respond.

2027.description: Adoption curves steepening. Nash equilibrium breaking for early incumbent defectors.

2028.description: Mainstream disruption. Significant employment and revenue shifts.

2029.description: Sector consolidation. Weak incumbents exiting. New firm structures emerging.

2030_2031.description: New sector structure stabilized. Dominant business models established.

fear_friction.notes: v3-9 deep dive confirms: LOW friction. Manufacturing transformation is ADDITIVE not substitutional — cobots augment workers who don't exist (499K shortage). Owner reluctance is about RETIREMENT not AI fear. Worker friction near zero (cobots do dangerous/repetitive tasks). 78-point implementation gap is capability not psychology.

narratives.name: Financial Services Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-6: Office CMBS 12.34% (all-time record, above 2008). CRE cascade chain validated. 3 new FS model cards scored (5239-001: 78.75, 5223-001: 78.5, 5239-002: 71.25). Mortgage servicing most extreme labor signal: 13.8% wage growth AND -10.7% employment simultaneously. RIA sector (523940) has 496K workers at $270K avg and extreme fragmentation — identified by sector screener as next FS deep-dive target.

2026.description: Rapid transformation in Financial Services. Multiple disruption vectors active simultaneously.

2027.description: Sector consolidation accelerating. Cascading exits among laggards.

2028.description: Employment restructuring. New roles emerging, legacy roles declining.

2029.description: New sector structure forming. Survivors adapting to new reality.

2030_2031.description: Transformation largely complete. Sector operating under new economics.

narratives.name: Retail Trade Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-8 DEEP DIVE (first ever): 15.53M workers = largest private employer, 1.07M establishments, Baumol 0.57 (LOW stored energy but MASSIVE absolute scale). Near-zero employment growth (+0.3%) while establishments grow (+1.3%) = fragmentation. Bifurcating: e-commerce 16-18% of sales growing vs physical retail 800+ closures in 2026. Retail media networks $69B new profit layer. Self-checkout 87% consumer adoption, cashierless 13.7% CAGR. Warehouse automation $181B by 2031. 3 STRUCTURAL_WINNERs in top 11 overall. Labor displacement concentrates on entry-level, young, female, minority workers = most politically sensitive displacement in economy.

2026.description: Disruption underway in Retail Trade. First entrants proving viability. Incumbents beginning to respond.

2027.description: Adoption curves steepening. Nash equilibrium breaking for early incumbent defectors.

2028.description: Mainstream disruption. Significant employment and revenue shifts.

2029.description: Sector consolidation. Weak incumbents exiting. New firm structures emerging.

2030_2031.description: New sector structure stabilized. Dominant business models established.

fear_friction.notes: NEW (v3-8). Consumer-side friction LOW (87% use self-checkout, cashierless accepted). Worker-side friction MODERATE but powerless (fragmented, non-unionized, high turnover masks displacement). Political friction HIGH (displacement concentrates on young, female, minority workers). Gap of 1 understates political sensitivity.

narratives.name: Healthcare Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-8 DEEP DIVE: 21.3M workers, 1.9M establishments, +4.5% employment growth. Healthcare monoculture (P-039) confirmed — 63% of Jan 2026 jobs. QCEW sub-sector data: Hospitals (622) 5.27M emp +3.7%, Ambulatory (621) 8.44M emp +4.1%, Nursing/Residential (623) 3.15M emp +5.5%, Social Assistance (624) 4.41M emp +5.6%. Nursing 8% national deficit, 250K RN gap by 2030. FDA AI deregulation + invisible pathway (admin→clinical). 34-pt provider-patient trust gap. PE record $190B+ deal value. Counter-signals: aging demographics create non-discretionary demand (95% seniors have 1+ chronic condition), monoculture may be structurally sustainable not fragile. 12 new model cards from deep dive.

2026.description: Disruption underway in Healthcare. First entrants proving viability. Incumbents beginning to respond.

2027.description: Adoption curves steepening. Nash equilibrium breaking for early incumbent defectors.

2028.description: Mainstream disruption. Significant employment and revenue shifts.

2029.description: Sector consolidation. Weak incumbents exiting. New firm structures emerging.

2030_2031.description: New sector structure stabilized. Dominant business models established.

fear_friction.notes: v3-8 deep dive: 34-pt provider-patient trust gap confirmed. 71% hospitals deployed predictive AI but via invisible pathway (admin, not clinical). FDA deregulation widens gap: economic readiness up but patients unaware. Healthcare AI creating NEW roles (data analysts, AI trainers) — friction may prolong transition rather than prevent it

narratives.name: Real Estate and Rental and Leasing Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-7 deep dive: 2.39M workers, most fragmented major sector (488K establishments, avg 4.9 workers). PRIMARY SECOND-ORDER CASCADE RECEPTOR: FS meltdown (CMBS 12.34%), remote work, AI workforce reduction all converge simultaneously. $936B debt maturity wall in 2026, office values 35-50% below 2020 peaks. NAR settlement + AI agents = existential pressure on 453K brokers (138K offices avg 3.3 workers). Baumol 1.03x = NOT a wage cure target, but STRUCTURAL fragmentation + cascade exposure.

2026.description: Rapid transformation in Real Estate and Rental and Leasing. Multiple disruption vectors active simultaneously.

2027.description: Sector consolidation accelerating. Cascading exits among laggards.

2028.description: Employment restructuring. New roles emerging, legacy roles declining.

2029.description: New sector structure forming. Survivors adapting to new reality.

2030_2031.description: Transformation largely complete. Sector operating under new economics.

fear_friction.notes: NEW (v3-7). NAR settlement already disrupting commission model. Agent resistance to AI intermediation high but fragmentation (4.9 workers/establishment) means no collective bargaining power.

narratives.name: Professional Services Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-6: 5 new model cards scored across sub-sectors (5415-001: 70.75, 5417-001: 69.5, 5417-002: 64.75, 5413-001: 68.5, 5416-001: 63.75). Legal services (5411) has highest fear friction of any professional sector at 82% ethical concern. IT services (5415) is self-disrupting: 2.46M workers, AI coding 19% SLOWER for experienced devs. Sector screener identifies 5415 as standalone deep-dive candidate.

2026.description: Disruption underway in Professional Services. First entrants proving viability. Incumbents beginning to respond.

narratives.name: Computer Systems Design and Related Services (IT Services) Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-7 deep dive: 2.46M workers, $366.8B payroll, Baumol 2.05x. Custom programming (541511) = 1.11M workers at $164K, highest direct AI substitution potential. 84% of developers using AI coding daily. BUT experienced devs 19% SLOWER on complex tasks. Employment flat (-0.4%) while wages +5% = classic Baumol squeeze onset. Extreme fragmentation (405K establishments, avg 6.1 workers). AI consulting growing 26-36% CAGR to $116B by 2035 even as traditional IT services compress.

2026.description: Disruption underway in Computer Systems Design and Related Services (IT Services). First entrants proving viability. Incumbents beginning to respond.

fear_friction.notes: NEW (v3-7). Workers ARE the AI builders/adopters. Low friction but self-disruption paradox: the sector building AI is most disrupted by it. 84% daily AI coding usage.

narratives.name: Educational Services Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-6: 8 education cards scored (avg 68.9, lowest batch due to fear friction). Brookings 50-country study confirms AI risks outweigh benefits for children. Ohio mandates AI frameworks by Jul 2026. Michigan chatbot liability for minors. Fear economy card (EDU-FEAR-01: 72.25) confirms fear creates market. College cliff NOW: 400 schools could close this decade, $18B endowment redistribution, 5 states = 75% of decline.

2026.description: Disruption underway in Educational Services. First entrants proving viability. Incumbents beginning to respond.

2027.description: Adoption curves steepening. Nash equilibrium breaking for early incumbent defectors.

2030_2031.description: New sector structure stabilized. Dominant business models established.

fear_friction.notes: CONFIRMED by Brookings 50-country study. Ohio mandates, Michigan chatbot liability. Entry sequence: corporate (gap 2) → teacher-facing (gap 2) → university admin (gap 3) → student-facing (gap 6).

narratives.name: Defense AI / National Security Technology Transformation
narratives.summary: UPGRADED early_disruption→acceleration (v3-6). 8 defense cards scored (avg 74.8, highest batch). MC-DEF-011 CMMC at 82.5 is strongest new card. Defense tech exits $54.4B (3x YoY) > investment ($49.1B) = first AI sector in Deployment phase. ReArm Europe EUR 800B. AUKUS autonomous warfare interoperability proven. Counter-UAS $7.5B budget. Nvidia/Groq $20B validates defense-AI hardware convergence.

2026.description: Rapid transformation in Defense AI / National Security Technology. Multiple disruption vectors active simultaneously.

narratives.name: Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Financial Investments Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-7 deep dive: 1.07M workers, $287B payroll, Baumol 3.71x (highest of any deep-dived sector). KEY DIVERGENCE: wages DECLINING (-2.4%) while employment GROWS (+4.1%) = structural shift from high-comp traders/analysts to lower-cost AI-augmented ops. Portfolio management (523940): 496K workers, 85K establishments avg 5.8 workers = classic rollup territory. RIA M&A record 345 deals ($1.22T transacted). 38% of advisors plan to retire within decade. Entry-level analyst hiring declining 24pp. Firms automating 60-70% of junior analyst tasks.

2026.description: Rapid transformation in Securities, Commodity Contracts, and Financial Investments. Multiple disruption vectors active simultaneously.

narratives.name: Micro-Firm AI Economy (Emerging Category) Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-9 DEEP DIVE (first emerging category dive): 33.9M addressable entities (30.4M nonemployers + 3.5M micro-employers). Coasean firm shrinkage confirmed: nonemployers +84% since 1997, 478K/month new business applications, avg firm size declining. Micro-firm taxonomy: Tier 1 (solo+AI, ~$500K-2M rev), Tier 2 (2-3 humans+AI, ~$2M-10M), Tier 3 (4-5 humans+AI, ~$5M-25M). Revenue per employee at AI-native companies 6x traditional SaaS ($3.48M vs $570K). Infrastructure stack 52% solved by point solutions, 48% gap = the opportunity. 10 model cards including AI OS (#1 actionable at 84.17 geo mean), Solopreneur Assistant (#3 actionable at 81.64), AI Accountant (80.5 transformation). 6 WIDE_OPEN, 4 ACCESSIBLE. First proper definition of emerging firm structure.

2026.description: Early signals of structural change in Micro-Firm AI Economy (Emerging Category). Cost curves shifting, technology proving feasible.

fear_friction.notes: NEW (v3-9). Economic readiness high (AI agents demonstrably capable, costs viable). Psychological barriers: Bench shutdown cautionary tale, trust for financial/legal AI guidance unproven at scale, solo practitioners habituated to manual processes. Gap narrows rapidly as Gen Z/Millennial founders adopt.

narratives.name: Management of Companies and Enterprises Transformation
narratives.summary: v3-7 deep dive: 2.55M workers, $375B payroll, Baumol 2.02x. This is the COMMAND AND CONTROL layer — corporate HQ, holding companies, regional offices. 55% routine-cognitive (reporting, budgets, status aggregation). Gartner: 20% of orgs eliminating >50% of middle management by 2026. McKinsey cutting 10% workforce. Coasean coordination cost collapse: when AI collapses coordination cost, this sector's rationale weakens. Employment projected to decline from 2.55M to 2.0-2.2M by 2031.

2026.description: Disruption underway in Management of Companies and Enterprises. First entrants proving viability. Incumbents beginning to respond.

fear_friction.notes: NEW (v3-7). Middle management resistance to AI that replaces coordination function. 60% anticipatory displacement but executives view AI as cost reduction tool, not threat to own role.
